subject: Grumpy Old Phan
event:
So I'm watching ESPN this morning and they've got a story about the upcoming playoff game between the Ravens and the Titans.  Ravens rookie QB Joe Flacco has been given a nickname by his teammates, the reporter announces -- "Joe Cool."

Pfui.  I have nothing against Joe Flacco, who seems to be a promising young talent, but why can't this new generation of NFL players make up their own fraking nicknames???  There's only one Joe Cool, and his last name was Montana, not Flacco.

And while I am on the subject, there's only one LT, and he was a linebacker for the New York Giants, not the oft-injured running back for that team in San Diego.

Next thing we know, ESPN will be telling us that some wet-behind-the-ears young kids just out of college want to be called "Night Train" and "Crazylegs."  Well, I saw it's spinach and I say the hell with it.

The commish needs to start slapping big fines on these clowns for inappropriate misappropriation of nicknames.

comments.article: Should've gone with Joe Camel.

I totally agree. I have been a football fan my whole life. As someone who for awhile thought the league was too harsh on these players who celebrate, I am totally flip flopping on the issue after these last couple of years. People like Chad Johnson don't shut up while there teams are being descimated. I am not a patriots fan but to see Wes Welker who I like a lot get fined TEN GRAND for a snow angel while half the league get's away with what you said and more I am dumbfounded. White shoes, Bradshaw and the first Joe Cool IMO, Joe Namath all had celebrations and names both earned and approaite. But lately, last week in fact I saw it twice, players celebrating after a first down or sack when there teams are losing, and losing big. Its awful and someone needs to teach these kids that football is the ultimate TEAM GAME, even the lowest players need to play a team game or your team loses and these absurd nicknames and dances, when players are losing, not playing or not earning it, is awful. Sorry for the rant, I needed to vent!!!
comments.subject: hahaha

comments.upictitle: The Kwisatz Haderach, Give A Dog A Bone: pic#80183639
comments.article:
Snoopy was the original Joe Cool.

Other than that, I agree. B-More's been waiting for a QB like him and we should give him a better name than Joe Cool. Unfortunately, my ideas for a nickname for Flacco are kind of lame. So far "The Unflappable Flacco" is the best I've got.
...and he's a dog. The rest should all be fined and/or booted from the Hall of Fame
comments.subject: There's only one Joe Cool...

comments.article: I thought Joe Montana's nickname was Big Sky.
We ran out of imagnination years ago.  Why does every scandal in America end in 'gate'?

First thing I though of was:

Tailgate

Nicknames for players dont bother me so much as when the press tries to come up with nicknames for today's defenses and end up hopelessly exploiting the names of the past greats.

That's sad.

Absolutely agree about LT. That's Lawrence Taylor. Period.

If some young turk comes along and thinks he'll be called Sweetness, there will be hell to pay.

But Joe Cool? That's Snoopy!

Wasn't Snoopy 'Joe Cool' first?

The LT thing annoys me to no end, though.
Retire of nicknames--if they can do it with jersey numbers, why not with nicknames?
Yes, Snoopy is the original Joe Cool. Joe Namath was never Joe Cool but Broadway Joe or less frequently, Joe Willie.

Joe Namath wasn't Joe Cool, but Montana was, and that's what GRRM was pointing out.

I prefer Joe Cool for Snoopy, myself.

Joe Cool was a dog, but in any case, they should be fined for unoriginality on that one.

What about Whacko Flacco?
Eyebrow Joe?

I'm still waiting on a nickname for D'Brickashaw Ferguson...although that might almost be redundant.

I'm also still crying that we lost to the RAIDERS and so the nickname for my team is the Schmuckaneers.

Joe had a great career, but every time I hear that name, I think of the devastation, the horror, I experienced with that dang, "the catch." I can watch that play over and over and still wonder how the heck he got that ball. It wasn't until after it that I realized that maybe SF was no longer a crappy team.

For Flacco, he doesn't even deserve a widely held nickname. So, as long as it's just the players calling him that, and not the media, then we're ok. It's bad enough that they confuse me with "LT" ...WTF are they thinking? There's only one LT, and this running back may have great ambitions, but he's got a long row to hoe before people will think of him before the true LT.
comments.subject: How about Dr. J(oe)

comments.article:
ok. sorry, Chargers fan here. the whole "people who get upset about the LT thing" is old news to us. let me say this clearly: THEY ARE HIS INITIALS. would you really get upset if someone named Guillermo Ramon Rivera Montes went around preferring to be called GRRM? of course not, because you don't have a monopoly on that particular combination of initials.

and while I'm at it, I will say that I will take my LT, who's been a model football citizen his entire career, over a cracked-out jailbird. for you to add the off-handed slight of "oft-injured" is both uninformed, and unbecoming, of someone who professes to love the game of football. Tomlinson has missed exactly 1 start in his career, and that was a meaningless final game in 2004 when the Chargers had clinched their playoff berth. it saddens me that, on the downside of his career, he may not be the same player he once was, but it saddens me even more that someone I'd admired for his football acumen can be as short-sighted as any fan(atic).

/rant

and while I'm at it, I will say that I will take my LT, who's been a model football citizen his entire career, over a cracked-out jailbird.

I think you have a point, there.

The LT thing always makes me do a double-take too!

The thing to remember about athletes is that they're athletes first aren't necessarily fans or scholars of the history of the game. Today's NFL players grew up after Montana's heyday and spent their childhoods playing football, not reading about football.

Football's also their job and after spending hundreds of hours a month gutting it out on the practice and gameday fields for the past decade or more of their lives, they probably don't necessarily feel like heading to the library and looking through old football magazines any more your friendly traffic meter reader enjoys spending their free time learning about the history of traffic meters. :)

oh yeah and while we're on the subject of blurring professional and personal lives, please finish Dance With Dragons plz kthx bai

...I'm surely going to hell now, huh? Well, if that's the sacrifice I need to make to find out what's next for Arya, so be it. Sooooo be it. Please find it in your heart to forgive me.

Although we are similar in age, I think here is where I tell you something like "Who is Joe Montana, old man?" Nicknames are going to be reused by the media and teams because the young have no memory for the past and the nicknames sound familiar to them but they have no frame of reference.

Get used to it, it comes with age...
Bite your tongue!

"FRAKing nicknames???"

You wouldn't happen to be a Battlestar Galactica fan, would you? If so I'd love to hear your Livejournaled thoughts on that series :-)
comments.subject: Frak that

comments.article: And they need to get off your lawn!
Maybe they mean "Joe Kewl" in these degenerate days.

I absolutely agree with you on the "LT" thing. Even if they are another player's initials, Lawrence Taylor was so well known by his nickname that it practically became his name in the profession. When actors join the Screen Actors Guild, if someone else has their name they have to register with a slightly different one and it should be the same with NFL nicknames :->
Word!
Snoopy is the only Joe Cool I know of.  :)

"There's only one Joe Cool, and his last name was Montana, not Flacco."

Sorry George. There's only one Joe Cool, and he's a beagle drawn by Charles Schultz.

comments.upictitle: Sean P. Fodera: Sean P. Lego
comments.article:
Maybe Flacco could go by "Joe Fairly-Relaxed".

And any Jet fan will tell you that "L.T." stands for "Lettuce and Tomato". Add on the Bacon, and you're talking my kind of abbreviation!
Excellent rant.  I don't even like football & enjoyed (and understood) it.  Rant on, sir!
No need to kiss ass just for the sake of it. It is that kind of sycophantic approach that encourages certain people to cultivate a lack of urgency when it comes to completing a certain task.
